Energy conservation between O and the highest point gives ½ m v₀² = ½ m v_h² + m g h + (U_h – U_O).
The work done by the electric force equals the change in the kinetic energy of the horizontal motion: q E Δx = ½ m v_h² – ½ m (v₀ cos θ)².
Using v₀ sin θ as the initial vertical speed and the vertical acceleration –g, h = (v₀² sin² θ)/(2 g).
Insert h from step 4 and eliminate v_h using step 3 inside step 2 to find U_h – U_O = –q E (v₀ cos θ)² /(2 E) + q E Δx = –q E Δx = –q E (v₀² cos² θ)/(2 m a_e).
Difference in electric potential energy (highest point minus at O) is ΔU = – qE · (v₀² cos² θ) / (2 g + 2 qE/m sin² θ).
The simplest form of the result is ΔU = – qE Δx, with Δx found from horizontal kinematics.
